article.title: Cold keV dark matter from decays and scatterings

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the DM distribution x²f(x,r→∞) for two competing decays A→BjDM (j = 1, 2), with branching ratios BRj and phase space suppression factors Δj = 1 - m²j/m²A. What does the figure illustrate about the impact of multiple decays on the DM momentum distribution?
choices: The DM momentum distribution always peaks at the lowest phase space suppression factor.
The DM momentum distribution is always dominated by the decay with the largest branching ratio.
The DM momentum distribution can have multiple peaks if the ratio of branching ratios is larger than the ratio of phase space suppression factors.
The DM momentum distribution is always a smooth curve, regardless of the branching ratios and phase space suppression factors.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure illustrates three different models for producing JDM via the process S₁S₁→S₂J. What types of interactions are shown in the figure?
choices: Two quartic interactions and one cubic interaction.
One quartic interaction and two cubic interactions.
Three cubic interactions.
One quartic interaction, one cubic interaction, and one Yukawa interaction.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares the cross sections σ(S₁S₁→S₂J) obtained from quartic and cubic interactions. What is the main observation regarding the behavior of the cross sections for large s (center-of-mass energy)?
choices: Cubic interactions decrease much faster than quartic ones for large s.
Quartic interactions decrease much faster than cubic ones for large s.
Both quartic and cubic interactions decrease at the same rate for large s.
Quartic interactions lead to a resonance peak for large s, while cubic interactions do not.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the resulting (p/T)prod for the three processes (quartic and two cubic interactions) as a function of the S₁,₂ mass ratio m₂/m₁. What does the figure demonstrate about the possibility of producing cold light DM?
choices: Only quartic interactions can produce cold light DM.
Cubic interactions with m₂>2m₁ can produce very cold light DM with (p/T)prod ~ 0.1.
All three processes lead to the same (p/T)prod, regardless of the mass ratio m₂/m₁.
The process S₁S₂→S₁J always leads to warmer DM than S₁S₁→S₂J.

multiple_choice_question.text: This formula relates the Lyman-α constraints on the DM mass for different production mechanisms. What is the key factor determining the coldness of DM in this formula?
choices: The DM mass MDM.
The average DM momentum at production temperature (p/T)prod.
The entropy number of degrees of freedom at production g*(Tprod).
The mass of the non-resonantly produced DM MNRP.
